50.text: Plato tells us about some people living imprisoned in a cave

54.text: They've always lived there and don't know anything of the outside world.

58.text: There is no natural light in this cave, the walls are damp and dark

62.text: All the inhabitants can see comes from the shadows of things thrown up on the wall by a light of a fire

91.text: Then one day, quite by chance, someone discovers a way out of the cave

97.text: At first, it's simply overwhelming. He is dazzled by the brilliant sunshine

101.text: In which everything is, for the first time, properly illuminated

105.text: Gradually his eyes adjust and he encounters the true forms

108.text: of all those things which he had formerly know only as shadows

112.text: He sees actual flowers, the colors of birds, the nuances in the bark of trees

118.text: He observes stars and grasps the vastness and sublime nature of the universe

242.text: The solution, Plato says, is a process of widespread carefully administered philosophical education

248.text: By which he understood the method of inquiry pioneered by Socrates and known to us as the "Socratic Method"

255.text: It's a very gentle process. You don't lecture or harang or force someone to read a particular book

261.text: You just start with a general declaration of intellectual modesty no one knows very much

266.text: It's always good to insist: "wisdom starts with owning up to ignorance"

270.text: Confess that you don't know exactly what the government should do, what wars meant to achieve or how good relationships work

277.text: You then get the other person to say what they think and gradually together you investigate the answers

283.text: Most likely the other person will be confident or rather painfully overconfident

288.text: They may tell you it's all quite simple really and everyone knows the answer already

292.text: You must be supremely patient with this kind of bravado

295.text: If they go off topic, you must cheerfully double back

298.text: You must take a lot of time and be ready to have chats over many days

302.text: This method of talking is founded on a lovely confidence that with the right encouragement

307.text: people can eventually work out things for themselves and detect errors in their own reasoning

317.text: and don't cast blame or ever get annoyed

319.text: You'll never teach anyone anything by making them feel stupid
